abstract.p: Recently, the benefit of nonlinear isolation systems under resonance or near-fault earthquake has been investigated. In this paper, an eccentric rolling isolation system (ERIS) with additional friction damping is proposed. The isolation object is eccentrically pinned on a set of circular isolators so that the restoring force is nonlinear. To investigate the advantage of the ERIS, a corresponding isolation system with linear restoring force is also considered for comparison. The friction parameters of the two systems with linear and nonlinear restoring force are designed under the far-field El Centro earthquake. The performances of the two isolation systems are inspected under excitations other than the design one. In free vibration, the response of the ERIS decays faster than the corresponding linear system. In resonance sinusoidal excitation, the responses are divergent for the linear system but convergent for the ERIS. The linear system is ineffective but the ERIS is effective due to the nonlinearity under the near-fault Chi-Chi earthquake with various peak ground accelerations.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Seismic isolation can mitigate structural responses under earthquake attack. For the conventional linear isolation systems, the restoring force is linear so that the frequency of the system is fixed. Several researches show that the responses of those linear isolation systems may be too large to meet the design requirement under near-fault earthquake due to resonance (Jangid and Kelly, 2001; Lu et al., 2003; Jangid, 2006). Such amplification effect of the linear isolation system under near-fault earthquake can be attenuated by an appropriate damping device. However, the nonlinear isolation system is another possible way to alleviate the resonant responses. Jangid and Londhe (1998) proposed a nonlinear elliptical rolling isolation system, by which the seismic responses of a multistory building supported on elliptical rods were effectively reduced. Elliptical rolling rods were found to be better than the circular ones and the larger the eccentricity, the lower was the peak and residual displacement. Butterworth (2006) proposed a rolling isolation system consisting of rollers with nonconcentric spherical upper and lower surfaces, in which the isolation period became a nonlinear function of the isolator displacement. Compared with a conventional isolator of constant vibration period, that roller system was able to reduce the peak acceleration with smaller reduction in peak displacement for high-intensity earthquakes. Virgin et al. (2008) proposed a new isolation system considering geometric nonlinearity for vertical isolation. The isolator was made of a thin strip that was bent so that the two ends are clamped together. The analysis revealed that the stiffness of the isolator could be tuned by assigning the geometric parameters of mass, loop length and loop self-weight. Cui et al. (2010) investigated the mechanical behavior of bidirectional spring units, which were used as isolators. The hysteretic loop showed that the bidirectional spring unit was bilinear and the branches of the loading and unloading path were different. Ismail et al. (2009a,b) proposed an innovative isolation: the so-called roll-n-cage (RNC) isolator. This isolator consisted of energy dissipation, a buffer and inherent gravity-based restoring force mechanisms. The analysis revealed the robust performance of the RNC isolator. The variable curvature pendulum isolator (VCPI) has also been studied and compared to the friction pendulum system (FPS). A four-story space building with the VCPI or FPS has been investigated numerically. From the results, the base shear of the building isolated by the VCPI with additional viscous fluid damper was less than the one isolated by the conventional FPS under near-fault earthquake. The residual displacements for the two cases were similar (Krishnamoorthy, 2010). Another idea of nonlinearity came from the composite material. Teng and Chen (2010) proposed a new isolator that consists of incompressible liquid and compressible elastic solid elements. This kind of isolator showed the nonlinear resorting force from the numerical and experimental studies. The potential of practical application has been proved for this kind of new isolator. In the mechanism field, Zhang et al. (2009) also indicated that the transmitted force around the resonant region of a system can be reduced by introducing appropriate nonlinear stiffness or damping.

These researches show that the isolation system with nonlinear behavior can be considered to improve the performances. Therefore, Chung et al. (2009) proposed the nonlinear rolling isolation system. The isolation object (mass) was pinned on the circular isolator eccentrically. The dynamic behavior of this isolator without damping was investigated numerically through free vibrations and forced vibrations with various eccentricities. The fundamental period of the isolation system varied with the amplitude of the rolling angle. Thus, the restoring force of this isolator was nonlinear. In resonance sinusoidal excitation, the responses of the proposed nonlinear isolator were convergent even without damping. The effectiveness of the proposed isolation system was better than the corresponding linear one under near-fault earthquake. However, energy dissipation is required for a well-designed system. Therefore, friction damping is considered for the eccentric rolling isolation system (ERIS) in this paper. The equation of the ERIS with the friction mechanism is derived by introducing Lagrange's equation; a numerical integration method is also proposed to solve the equation of motion with two nonlinearities: friction and eccentricity. Once the equation of motion is obtained, the eccentricity is chosen so that the linearized frequency of the ERIS falls into the range for common isolation systems. A corresponding isolation system with linear restoring force and friction damping is also established for comparison. The stiffness of the corresponding isolation system can be converted from the linearized frequency of the ERIS. The normal force for the friction mechanism of the ERIS and the friction coefficient for the sliding interface of the linear system are optimized by minimizing the maximum absolute acceleration of the mass block under the design earthquake, the El Centro earthquake. However, the isolation systems may encounter an excitation other than the design one in terms of intensity and waveform. Therefore, the behavior of the two systems with linear and nonlinear restoring forces subjected to free vibration, sinusoidal excitation and far-field and near-fault earthquakes with various intensities is studied. Finally, the robustness and the performance in isolation effectiveness of the two systems are compared and verified.

sec.title: 2. Eccentric rolling isolation system with friction
sec.p:
The proposed ERIS can be implemented for the isolation of structures and equipments (Figure 1). To investigate the nonlinear behaviors and features of the ERIS, it is simplified as a single-degree-of-freedom ERIS with friction washers on each circular isolator, as shown in Figure 2. The mass m represents the super structure or any expensive facilities. The isolation object is pin connected to the circular isolator eccentrically. The link between the mass and the pin is considered to be rigid. The distance between the center of the circular isolator and the pin is αR. The eccentricity α describes the location of the pin on the circular isolator with radius R. If eccentricity (α) equals zero, the mass is pinned at the center of isolator. On the other hand, if the eccentricity is close to one, the mass is similar to that fixed at the ground. The dynamic behavior is nonlinear for the ERIS while the eccentricity (α) is greater than zero and smaller than 1 (0<α<1). The additional friction damper is installed on the rigid link with distance αR from the pin (Figure 2). In other words, the friction damper locates at the center of the circular isolator if the system lies on the lowest position. μd is the friction coefficient between the circular isolator and the friction damper. The normal force (N) of the friction damper can be tuned by the bolts. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram for implementation of the eccentric rolling isolation system (ERIS). Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of the eccentric rolling isolation system. (a) Side view. (b) Front view (lowest position). (c) Front view (displaced position).

In order to derive the equation of motion, the coordinates are defined and shown in Figure 3. The rigid link connects the mass block and the circular isolator, so the mass can be thought of as a lumped mass at the pin. In this study, the rolling angle θ is the only one degree of freedom to describe the system motion and Xg is the displacement of the ground. Thus, the position vector tX⇀ of the pin is expressed as follows: (1)tX⇀=[(Rθ-αRsinθ)+Xg]i+(R-αRcosθ)j where i and j are the unit vectors of the horizontal axis and the vertical axis, respectively. Taking the derivative of Equation (1), the velocity vector tV⇀ is given as (2)tV⇀=dtX⇀dt=∂tX⇀∂θdθdt+∂tX⇀∂XgdXgdt=[(R-αRcosθ)θ·+X·g]i+[(αRsinθ)θ·]j Figure 3.
Eccentric rolling isolator.
The acceleration vector tA⇀ shown in Equation (3) is achieved by taking the derivative of Equation (2): (3)tA⇀=[(R-αRcosθ)θ··+αRsinθ·θ·2+X··g]i+[(αRsinθ)θ··+αRcosθ·θ·2]j

In this research, the motion equation is derived by introducing Lagrange's equation as follows: (4)ddt(∂L∂θ·)-∂L∂θ=QN where QN is the nonconservative force of the corresponding degree of freedom; L(Lagrangian) is the difference between kinetic energy (T) and potential energy (U). The kinetic energy of the system is (5)T=12m|tV⇀|2=12m[R2θ·2+α2R2θ·2-2αR2cosθ·θ·2+2X·g(R-αRcosθ)θ·+X·g2]
The potential energy is (6)U=mgαR(1-cosθ)
From Equations (5) and (6), the Lagrangian (L) becomes (7)L=T-U=[12mR2θ·2-mαR2cosθ·θ·2+12mα2R2θ·2 +mX·g(R-αRcosθ)θ·+12mX·g2]-mgαR(1-cosθ)
Substituting Equation (7) into Equation (4) gives (8)(mR2+mα2R2-2mαR2cosθ)θ··+mαR2sinθ·θ·2 +mgαRsinθ+[mR-mαRcosθ]X··g=QN
Reordering Equation (8) gives (9)(mR2+mα2R2-2mαR2cosθ)θ··+mαR2sinθ·θ·2 +mgαRsinθ-QN=-[mR-mαRcosθ]X··g

In this paper, the degree of freedom is a rolling angle (θ), so that the corresponding nonconservative force should be a moment. In Figure 4 the normal force, Nv, from the ground is the vertical reaction force, and the horizontal friction force, fg, between the isolator and ground is assumed to be large enough to ensure that only the rolling behavior will occur. If the rolling acceleration of the isolator is in the clockwise direction, the friction force, fg, is applied to the left to generate a clockwise moment to the isolator. If the center of the circular isolator is considered as the reference point, the trajectory of the friction damper forms a quarter-cycle on the isolator when the rolling angle is equal to 90 degrees. When the ERIS is in motion, the circular isolator can be considered as rotating around the pin, and the rigid link keeps vertical. Therefore, the velocity of the friction damper relative to the isolator at the contact point remains horizontal, resulting in the horizontal damper friction force, fr. The energy-dissipating nonconservative moment induced by the friction damper is equal to the friction force (fr) multiplying the moment arm (αR). The work done by this nonconservative moment is negative. Finally, the whole situation results: (10)QN=-frαR Figure 4.
Free body diagram of isolator (θ=90∘).

Substituting Equation (10) into Equation (9), the equation of motion of the proposed isolation system is obtained as follows: (11)(mR2+mα2R2-2mαR2cosθ)θ··+mαR2sinθ·θ·2 +mgαRsinθ+frαR=-[mR-mαRcosθ]X··g

In this study, the performance index ra is defined as (12)ra=max|x··H(t)|max|X··g(t)| which represents the transmissibility of horizontal acceleration. The absolute acceleration in the horizontal direction (x··H) can be calculated from the i component of Equation (3). If this acceleration ratio is smaller than one, the isolation system is effective to reduce the ground acceleration. The isolation system is designed such that this acceleration ratio is as small as possible.

sec.title: 3. Simulation process of the eccentric rolling isolation system with friction
sec.p: In many researches of dynamic system with friction, a method of so-called shear balance is used to simulate this kind of nonlinear system (Wang et al., 2001; Lu et al., 2006). In a dynamic system with friction, the motion of the system is in either slip or stick state. The system is assumed in the stick state at the (k+1)st time step; the rolling velocity is zero at this moment. Adopting the first-order Euler formula, the rolling velocity at the (k+1)st step can be approximated by the rolling velocity and the rolling acceleration of the previous step as (13)θ·[k+1]=θ·[k]+11!Δtθ··[k]=0

The rolling acceleration at the kth step can be obtained by rewriting Equation (11) as (14)θ··[k]=(-{mαRsinθ[k]·θ·[k]2+mgαsinθ[k] +(m-mαcosθ[k])X··g[k]+fr[k]·α})(mR+mα2R-2mαRcosθ[k]) At the kth step, θ[k] and θ·[k] are already known but the friction force fr[k] is still unknown. By substituting Equation (14) into Equation (13) and reordering, an approximation model of the friction force f~r[k] at the kth step is obtained as (15)f~r[k]=(mR+mα2R-2mαRcosθ[k])θ·[k]Δt·α-mαRsinθ[k]·θ·[k]2+mgαsinθ[k]+(m-mαcosθ[k])X··g[k]α

In Equation (15), the stick assumption may not hold true in the real situation of the system. If the system is in the real stick state, the real friction force is the same as the predicted one: (16)fr[k]=f~r[k]

If the system is in the real slip state, the magnitude of the real friction force is equal to the maximum one and the direction is the same as the predicted one: (17)fr[k]=μdNsgn(f~r[k]) where μdN is the maximum friction force provided by normal force (N) from the bolts. The friction force (fr) is modeled by Coulomb's friction. Considering Equations (16) and (17), the real friction force is determined by the predicted friction force and the maximum friction force as (18)fr[k]=min(|f~r[k]|,μdN)sgn(f~r[k])

The numerical simulation process is divided into three procedures. Firstly, assume that the system is in the stick state at the (k+1)st step so the predicted friction force at the kth step can be calculated by Equation (15). Secondly, the real friction force can be determined by checking Equation (18). Thirdly, the state of the system at the (k+1)st step can be solved by Equation (11) after the real friction force is obtained. These procedures can be executed repeatedly until the whole time history is obtained. The ODE45 function in MATLAB software is adopted to solve this nonlinear numerical integration of Equation (11).

sec.title: 4. Corresponding isolation system with linear restoring force
sec.p:
To demonstrate the dynamic behavior of the ERIS, a corresponding ‘linear’ system with linear restoring force is established, as shown in Figure 5. The restoring force provided by the spring is linear but the energy dissipated by the friction mechanism is nonlinear. The spring stiffness is designed such that the natural frequency of the ‘linear’ system is the same as the linearized frequency of the ERIS. If the responses in Equation (11) are small enough, the linearized frequency of the ERIS is expressed as (19)f0=12πmgαR(mR2+mα2R2-2mαR2)=12π(1-α)αgR Figure 5.
Schematic diagram of the corresponding linear isolation system.

Once the eccentricity (α) and the radius of the circular isolator are decided, the linearized frequency is determined. The stiffness of the corresponding ‘linear’ isolation system is calculated by k=m(2πf0)2. The friction coefficient (μi) between the mass and the ground is determined such that the absolute acceleration of the mass under a design earthquake is minimized.

sec.title: 5. Numerical analysis
sec.p: Both the proposed ERIS and the corresponding linear isolation system are designed and simulated. Isolation of a facility with mass of 1 ton is considered. The two systems are different in mechanism. The design parameters for the ERIS and the linear system are normal force (N) and friction coefficient (μi), respectively. The optimal friction coefficient for the linear system will not change if the mass is scaled. On the other hand, the optimal normal force for the ERIS should be scaled proportionally with the mass of the isolated object. These two parameters are designed (optimized) by minimizing the maximum absolute acceleration under the familiar far-field El Centro earthquake. Based on the same optimal design procedures, those dynamic behaviors and features of the two systems are compared and discussed under free vibration and forced vibration by sine wave, far-field and near-fault earthquake excitations.

sec.title: 5.1. System parameters of the eccentricity rolling isolation system
sec.p:
The parameters of the ERIS are m = 1 ton, R = 1 m and μd = 0.1. When the eccentricity (α) equals 0.3, the linearized frequency (f0) (Equation (19)) is 0.39 Hz. This linearized frequency belongs to the range from 0.33 to 0.5 Hz, which is converted from the familiar isolation periods in the range from 2 to 3 seconds (Naeim and Kelly, 1999; Yang et al., 2005). Therefore the eccentricity equal to 0.3 is selected. The undamped free vibration of the ERIS with different initial angles is simulated first by using Equation (11) and setting the friction force (fr) to be zero. The fundamental frequency of the ERIS varies with the initial angle (Figure 6). When the initial angle increases from 5 to 90 degrees, the fundamental frequency decreases from 0.389 to 0.258 Hz. The restoring force is provided by the eccentricity and the mass block. The system is stable as long as the rolling angle is within 180 degrees. Consequently, the ERIS is quite different from the linear system, in which the frequency of the system is fixed. Figure 6.
Fundamental frequency versus initial angle (θ0) (α=0.3).

The original far-field El Centro earthquake with peak ground acceleration (PGA) equal to 3.42 m/sec2 is selected to be the design earthquake. The normal force N is optimized by minimizing the absolute acceleration of the mass block under the design earthquake (Figure 7(a)). When the normal force N equals zero, the maximum absolute acceleration and maximum displacement of the ERIS are 2.49 m/sec2 and 0.583 m, respectively. The ERIS without friction already shows some effectiveness from the acceleration ratio, which is 0.727. The minimal absolute acceleration of the mass block occurs at the optimal normal force (N) equal to 12.15 kN. According to this optimal point, the maximum absolute acceleration and maximum displacement are 0.898 m/sec2 and 0.0647 m, respectively (Figure 7). The acceleration ratio is 0.263 due to the optimal normal force. From the results, the ERIS with friction damping is more effective in reducing displacement and acceleration responses than the one without damping. Figure 7.
Optimization of normal force for the eccentric rolling isolation system (ERIS) (El Centro). (a) Maximum absolute acceleration. (b) Maximum displacement.

sec.title: 5.2. System parameters of the corresponding linear isolation system
sec.p:
In the corresponding linear system, the mass equal 1 ton, which is the same as in the ERIS. Its stiffness is converted from the linearized frequency of the ERIS as k=m(2πf0)2. The rate of energy dissipation is controlled by the friction coefficient (μi) multiplied by the weight of the mass block, and this coefficient should be designed appropriately. The design procedure for the friction coefficient in the linear system is similar to the design for the normal force (N) in the ERIS. The friction coefficient (μi) of the linear system is optimized by minimization of the absolute acceleration of the mass block under the El Centro earthquake. If the friction coefficient μi equals zero, the maximum absolute acceleration and maximum displacement are 2.19 m/sec2 and 0.364 m, respectively (Figure 8). The acceleration ratio equal to 0.639 also shows acceleration reduction for the linear system without friction. After the optimization, the optimal reduction in absolute acceleration of the linear isolation system occurs at the friction coefficient μi equal to 0.053 (Figure 8(a)). At this moment, the maximum absolute acceleration and maximum displacement are 0.902 m/sec2 and 0.0637 m, respectively (Figure 8). The acceleration ratio is reduced from 0.614 to 0.264 due to the friction mechanism. The friction effect is useful to further reduce both displacement and acceleration. Figure 8.
Optimization of friction coefficient for linear system (El Centro). (a) Maximum absolute acceleration. (b) Maximum displacement.

Comparing the optimization results of the two isolation systems, the maximum displacements are 0.0637 and 0.0647 m for the linear system and the ERIS, respectively. Similarly, the maximum absolute accelerations are 0.902 and 0.898 m/sec2 for the linear system and the ERIS, respectively. It is clear that the performances of the two isolation systems are very close under the specific design earthquake. However, it is impossible that the two systems encounter an earthquake exactly the same as the design one during their service lives. In the isolation system, the response of the system under far-field and near-fault earthquake may be quite different due to the different characteristics of the two waveforms. For the reasons above, the behavior of the two isolation systems is further investigated under various nondesign excitations, including free vibration, sinusoidal excitation, far-field El Centro and near-fault Chi-Chi earthquakes with different PGAs. After these simulations, the performances and robustness of the two isolation systems can be fully verified.

sec.title: 5.3. Comparisons of two isolation systems under free vibration
sec.p:
When the two isolation systems are subjected to free vibration, the initial displacement of the linear system is 0.573 m, which can be converted to the initial angle equal to 45 degrees for the ERIS. In Figure 9(a), the peak values of absolute accelerations for the linear system and the ERIS after one cycle are 1.88 and 1.59 m/sec2, respectively. After one cycle of free vibration, the peak displacements equal to 0.227 m for the linear system occur at t = 2.56 sec and 0.190 m and for the ERIS at t = 2.75 sec (Figure 9(b) and Table 1). Obviously, the responses of the ERIS are smaller than the linear system. The frequency of the first cycle for the linear system and the ERIS are 0.3906 and 0.3636 Hz, respectively. In Figure 9(b), the linear system is in the stick state with residual displacement equal to 0.0539 m after t = 3.85 sec. For the ERIS, the system is in the stick state with residual displacement equal to 0.0166 m after t = 4.05 sec. Figure 9.
(a) Absolute acceleration time histories under free vibration (b) Displacement time histories under free vibration. (c) Hysteretic loops under free vibration. Table 1.

Max. relative disp. (m) 0.227 0.190

From the results of free vibration, the responses of displacement and acceleration of the ERIS are smaller than the linear system when the friction parameters of the two systems are optimally designed. The responses of the ERIS decay a little faster than the linear system. In hysteretic loops (Figure 9(c)), the absolute value of base shear of the ERIS is smaller than the linear system after the half cycle due to nonlinearity, and the absolute value of displacement of the ERIS is also smaller at this moment.

sec.title: 5.4. Comparisons of two isolation systems under forced vibration: sine wave
sec.p: The sine wave excitation is assigned with amplitude 0.981 m/sec2 (0.1 g) and duration 23 cycles. The amplitude increases gradually in the first three cycles until the desired amplitude 0.981 m/sec2 (0.1 g) is reached. Three excitation frequencies (fext), which are fext=0.5f0, fext=f0 and fext=2f0, are considered to simulate the responses of the isolation system subjected to disturbances of low frequency, resonant and high frequency.

In the case of fext=0.5f0, the total simulation time is 102.6 seconds. In acceleration, 1.82 and 1.79 m/sec2 are the maximum absolute accelerations for the linear system and the ERIS, respectively (Table 2). The maximum displacements of the linear system and the ERIS are 0.217 and 0.226 m, respectively. From these results, the responses of the two isolation system are similar and both of the two systems are ineffective under this specific sine wave with lower frequency. Table 2.

In the case of fext=f0, the total simulation time is 51.3 seconds. The absolute acceleration histories are shown in Figure 10(a); the maximum absolute accelerations of the linear system and the ERIS are 18.1 and 2.98 m/sec2, respectively (Table 2). These two maximum values are both larger than the excitation amplitude 0.981 m/sec2 (0.1 g), so both of the two isolation systems are ineffective under this excitation. Figure 10(b) shows the displacement histories; the maximum displacement of the ERIS is 0.668 m (Table 2), which is 22.8% of the linear system. From the time histories of both displacement and acceleration, it is clear that the responses of the linear system increase rapidly and divergently due to the resonance (Chopra, 2001). However, the responses for the ERIS are magnified but bounded under this resonance case. The nonlinear behavior in the ERIS can be clearly observed in the hysteretic loop (Figure 10(c)). Figure 10.
(a) Absolute acceleration time histories under sinusoidal excitation (fext=f0). (b) Displacement time histories under sinusoidal excitation (fext=f0). (c) Hysteretic loops under sinusoidal excitation (fext=f0).

When the frequency of the sine wave changes to double that of the linearized frequency (fext=2f0), the total simulation time is 25.6 seconds. The maximum absolute accelerations for the linear and the ERIS are both 0.734 m/sec2 (Table 2). These two maximum absolute acceleration values show that the two isolation systems are effective to isolate the ground acceleration. The maximum displacements of the linear system and the ERIS are 0.0357 and 0.0368 m, respectively. The displacement of the ERIS is 103.1% that of the linear one.

In order to extend the investigation, the frequency of the sine wave is broadened to the range between 0.1 to 3 times of the linearized frequency and the amplitude still remains 0.981 m/sec2 (0.1 g). The simulation results are shown in Figure 11. The performances of the two isolation systems are very close when the frequency ratio is smaller than 0.75 or larger than 1.25. The two isolation systems are effective only when the frequency ratio is larger than 1.5. When the frequency ratio is close to 1 (fext=f0), the resonant effect for the ERIS is much smaller than the linear isolation system. In other words, the isolation system with the linear restoring force and friction mechanism may fail when subjected to resonant sinusoidal excitation. Figure 11.
(a) Acceleration ratios versus frequency ratio. (b) Maximum displacements versus frequency ratio.

sec.title: 5.5. Comparisons of two isolation systems under forced vibration: seismic excitation
sec.p:
One of the applications of isolation systems is to suppress vibration responses under seismic excitation. The El Centro (far-field) earthquake and Chi-Chi (near-fault) earthquake are taken into consideration. The amplitude of the El Centro earthquake is scaled up to 5.89 m/sec2 (0.6 g) (Figure 12(a)) so that the intensity is different from the design one. The maximum values of the absolute horizontal accelerations for the linear system and the ERIS are 1.69 and 1.58 m/sec2, respectively (Figure 12(b) and Table 3). Converting to acceleration ratios, it gives 0.286 and 0.268 for the linear system and the ERIS, respectively (Table 3). The peak value of vertical acceleration for the ERIS equal 0.534 m/sec2, which is just 33.9% of the peak value in the horizontal direction (Figure 12(c)). The maximum velocities for the linear system and the ERIS are 0.696 and 0.702 m/sec, respectively (Table 3). The maximum displacements of the linear system and the ERIS are 0.194 and 0.196 m, respectively (Figure 12(d) and Table 3). The responses of the two systems are very close, because the displacement is so small that the nonlinear behavior of the ERIS has not been developed. It can be observed from the hysteretic loop of the ERIS (Figure 12(e)) that the system is just at the onset of the softening stage. Figure 12.

In order to study the robustness of the two systems due to earthquake intensity, the PGA of the far-field El Centro earthquake is extended from 0.491 to 7.85 m/sec2 (0.05–0.8 g). The performances of the two systems are quite similar in both displacement and acceleration when the amplitude of the earthquake excitation is smaller than the design one (PGA: 3.42 m/sec2) (Figure 13). However, compared with the linear system, the isolation effect of the ERIS becomes better and better as the PGA of the excitation becomes larger and larger (Figure 13(a)). The higher the excitation intensity, the greater is the degree of the nonlinear behavior of the ERIS. Nonlinearity makes the ERIS more effective in reduction in absolute acceleration. Figure 13.
(a) Acceleration ratios versus peak ground acceleration (PGA) (El Centro). (b) Maximum absolute accelerations versus PGA (El Centro). (c) Maximum displacements versus PGA (El Centro).

The performances of the two systems are further investigated by using seismic excitation with different waveforms: the near-fault Chi-Chi (TCU102) earthquake. The PGA of the excitation is scaled to 5.89 m/sec2 (0.6 g) (Figure 14(a)). The maximum absolute horizontal acceleration and acceleration ratio for the linear system are 9.85 m/sec2 and 1.67, respectively. The maximum absolute horizontal acceleration and vertical acceleration for the ERIS are 3.32 m/sec2 and 3.38 m/sec2, respectively, and the horizontal acceleration ratio is 0.565 (Figure 14(b), (c) and Table 3). It is obvious that the linear system is ineffective but the ERIS is effective. Compared with the linear system, the absolute acceleration of the ERIS is not only much less in maximum value but also convergent at a much faster rate (Figure 14(b)). The maximum displacement and velocity for the linear system are 1.55 m and 4.50 m/sec, respectively (Figure 14(d) and Table 3). For the ERIS, the maximum displacement and velocity are 1.47 m and 2.37 m/sec, respectively. Although the maximum displacements of the two systems are close, the vibration of the ERIS decays much faster than the linear system (Figure 14(d)). Unlike the situation under the El Centro earthquake with the same PGA (Figure 12(e)), the nonlinear behavior of the ERIS under Chi-Chi earthquake is fully developed (Figure 14(e)). The stiffness softening is very evident. Nonlinearity makes the ERIS superior to the linear one under near-fault earthquake. Figure 14.

(c) Vertical absolute acceleration time histories (Chi-Chi, PGA: 5.89 m/sec2). (d) Displacement time histories (Chi-Chi, PGA: 5.89 m/sec2). (e) Hysteretic loops (Chi-Chi, PGA: 5.89 m/sec2).

Similarly, the robustness of the two systems under the variation of intensity of the near-fault Chi-Chi earthquake is also studied. In Figure 15(a), the linear system is ineffective when the PGA is larger than 3.43 m/sec2 (0.35 g) and may be slightly effective when the PGA is smaller than 3.43 m/sec2 (0.35 g). Compared to the linear system, the effectiveness of the ERIS is much better than the linear system and it becomes better and better when the PGA increases. Observing the maximum absolute acceleration in Figure 15(b), the maximum absolute accelerations of the two systems are close when the PGA is smaller than the 3.43 m/sec2 (0.35 g). However, the difference between the linear system and the ERIS becomes much evident when the PGA is larger than the 3.43 m/sec2 (0.35 g). The performances of the two systems in maximum displacement are very close no matter what the PGA is (Figure 15(c)). Consequently, the ERIS may perform better than the linear system with similar displacement demand under the Chi-Chi earthquake. The robustness of the ERIS under the Chi-Chi earthquake is also confirmed. Figure 15.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, the feasibility and the robustness of the proposed ERIS with additional friction damping is verified successfully through simulations with different types of nondesign excitations. The ERIS with friction damping shows that it is superior to the corresponding linear isolation system. The friction parameters for the two systems are designed by minimizing the absolute acceleration of the mass block under 100% El Centro earthquake. The performances of the two systems are very close under the design earthquake. In free vibration, the simulation results show that the response of the ERIS decays a little bit faster than the linear system. If the excitation changes to sinusoidal excitation with amplitude equal to 0.981 m/sec2 (0.1 g), the responses are divergent for the linear system but convergent for the ERIS under resonance. When the seismic excitation is considered, the performances of the isolation systems are different under far-field or near-fault earthquake. In far-field El Centro earthquake with the PGA varying from 0.491 to 7.85 m/sec2 (0.05–0.8 g), both of the two isolation systems are effective with similar performance in displacement when the PGA is larger than 0.491 m/sec2 (0.05 g). The performance of the ERIS in acceleration becomes better and better when the PGA is larger than 4.41 m/sec2 (0.45 g). The ERIS is 87.44% of the linear system in maximum acceleration when the PGA increases to 7.85 m/sec2 (0.8 g). Then, the near-fault Chi-Chi earthquake with intensity varying from 0.491 to 7.85 m/sec2 (0.05–0.8 g) is also studied. For the performance of maximum acceleration, the linear system is almost ineffective in this range of PGA. However, the ERIS is obviously effective when the PGA is larger than 0.491 m/sec2 (0.05 g). The ERIS is 22.34% of the linear system in maximum acceleration when the PGA is 7.85 m/sec2 (0.8 g). The performances of maximum displacement for the two systems are also close. Consequently, the performance and robustness of the proposed ERIS with additional friction damping is significantly better than the corresponding linear system under these excitations, other than the design one.
